title.narrative: Support the IDPs and vulnerable households of the host communities through undertaking the rehabilitation of their damaged and unfinished shelters

description.narrative: This project seeks to strengthen the protective environment for 2000 (422 men,522 women, girls:550, boys: 522) conflict-affected persons (1397 IDPs,439 hosted people, 164 returnees ), in northwest Syria by improving the living conditions, through tailored shelter solutions willing to enhance the sense of privacy for them and mitigate the protection risks to women and young girls, who will no longer have to use shared spaces and utility services by providing the primary shelter needs such as: providing a source of lighting energy (solar system), Walls and roofs preparation (plastering, maintenance, repairs), promote the protection and water services and sanitation in these shelters, As well as fiber pan which will be installed for windows to protect the families form cold weather Waves of conflict have caused population displacement and severe damages to housing and infrastructures across northwest Syria, essentially along with the project areas, impacting the living conditions of the affected populations, IDPs, Returnees, and the host communities. The lack of adequate shelter options has led to housing shortages and an increase in rental prices, affecting the most vulnerable population. SECD is aiming to conduct non-structural repairs for 400 Damaged and unfinished houses in Baksariya, Hanbushiyeh) communities in Badama sub-district, Jisr-Ash-Shugur district, Idleb governorate to ensure that those households have dignified and safe shelters with a specific emphasis on people with disabilities and women-headed households, SECD is aiming to respond in the previous two communities, and will conduct a deep need assessment, and Household Selection and verification and ensure covering the completion shelter need of each community, SECD is aiming to cover the needs to shelter rehabilitation according to the selection criteria in the targeted communities with paying attention to assure that the intervention achieved the full coverage in each community and that will be with the coordination with the other actors and the SNFI cluster. SECD will select 400 vulnerable households ( in need of household-level shelter repairs according to HLP-relevant eligibility criteria following a thorough HLP rights Due Diligence process, as developed by the Turkey Hub SNFI cluster in 2019 After the selection, SECD will develop specifically tailored Bill of Quantities (BoQs) for each shelter. The repairs will be conducted by local contractors with the field team of SECD supervision ensuring that all rehabilitation works are conducted in line with the agreed BOQs. The intervention will focus on supporting the vulnerable families in a cost-effective, durable and environmentally friendly manner by ensuring that the BOQ table is providing the access to all the shelter facilities especially the WASH facilities and the provision of solar systems to the targeted houses were needed to use for lighting purposes to increase the privacy and to provide more protection for the vulnerable segments in the community This intervention is complementing with other SECD multi-sectorial interventions in the targeted areas ( WASH – CCCM – SNFI ) and it is designed based on its need assessment and the discussion with the local communities who are not able to deal with this challenge to ensure that the vulnerable people are living in a safe shelter, SECD is aware that needs are different amongst gender and age groups, and other vulnerable groups such as people with disabilities. SECD aims to provide the most needed assistance to such groups through, Establishing beneficiary selection criteria to priorities the inclusion of those most vulnerable and adapting its assistance delivery to promote access for the most vulnerable people. The households and/or shelters will be selected for this project will be chosen based on need and without the interference of authorities or armed actors.
